column1: http://educainternet.es/excursions/182#"NOMOFOBIA"#"NOMOFOBIA - Abel Pichardo"#"Esta presentación se presenta como una introducción para trabajar con los alumn@s todo el tema relacionado con las tecnoadicciones y el uso responsable del teléfono móvil.En la Slide 1: se introduce el tema llevando a los alumnos a qu ese den cuenta de que hay muchas adicciones en el mundo que les rodea.En la Slide 2: se le muestra al alumno un vídeo con una serie de cuestiones a las que debe ir respondiendo de forma personal.En la Slide 3: se ve que si la mayoría de mis respuestas son positivas puede ser que tengo un problema respecto a la dependencia que tengo del móvil
column2: o si por el contrario son negativas (o los alumnos que en primer lugar han dado al positivo)
column3: ven que pautas pueden o deben seguir para hacer un uso responsable del móvil

column1: http://vishub.org/excursions/1786#"Build an atom"#"Build an atom - ViSH"#"This Inquiry Learning Space is designed for young Chemistry students of lower secondary school (12-15 years old) and aims at introducingan atom’s main ""building blocks"": protons
column2: neutron and electrons.Students will “build” atoms through the addition or removal of protons
column3: neutrons and electrons. Through this activity they will discover in a fun

atom
* The link of the number of particles with the mass and atomic number of an
atom
* The link of the number of protons with the position of an element in the
atomic table.

column2: μάλιστα
column3: είχε επιχειρηματολογήσει υπέρ μιας σφαιρικής γης πιστεύοντας ότι οι καμπύλες γραμμές στη σεληνιακή επιφάνεια δημιουργούνται από τη σκιά μιας σφαιρικής γης
column4: που παρεμβάλλεται ανάμεσα στον ήλιο και το φεγγάρι (Grant 2011
column6: για μαθητές τυπικής ανάπτυξης και μαθητἐς με ειδικές εκπαιδευτικές ανάγκες ή/και αναπηρία
column7: είναι η συμμετοχή στο διαγωνισμό Εκπαιδευτικού Σεναρίου τουOpen Discovery Space (ODS) 2014-15. Ανήκει στο διερευνητικό μοντέλο μάθησης και έμφαση δόθηκε στη σύνδεση του περιεχομένου με την καθημερινή ζωή
column9: Πιερράτος 2013) και στις μεγάλες ιδέες της επιστήμης (Harlen 2010). Αυτή η διδακτική πρόταση υποστηρίζεται από ένα σχέδιο διδασκαλίας (δείτε εδώ: http://wp.me/p3oRiZ-eW) και Χώρους Διερευνητικής Μάθησης χώρους (ILS) στα Ελληνικά και Αγγλικά. Οι μαθητές εργάζονται σε ομάδες και καλούνται να συμμετάσχουν σε μια διερεύνηση του φαινομένου της σκιάς με χρήση διαδραστικού πίνακα και του μαθησιακού αντικειμένου «Σκιά – Παρασκιά” από photodentro.edu.gr (δείτε εδώ http://goo.gl/iwW0zh). Επιπλέον

column1: http://vishub.org/excursions/1799#"Discover the Z boson"#"Discover the Z boson - ViSH"#"Students will use the experimental data collected by the ATLAS experiment at CERN to “discover” invisible particles and calculate their mass. For this purpose they will identify different lepton types and use Einstein’s famous equation for the equivalence of mass and energy. They will also us vector addition to add the momenta of several particles which are the decay products of the invisible particles. The particle they will be looking for is the particle responsible for the weak force
column2: the Z boson.

column1: http://vishub.org/excursions/1359#"Tipología de las fortificaciones"#"Tipología de las fortificaciones - Mikel Rodríguez"#"Finalizada la Guerra Civil
column2: Franco decidió la fortificación de la frontera con Francia. Con ese objetivo se iniciaron las obras que
column3: con mayor o menor intensidad
column4: prosiguieron hasta una fecha tan avanzada como 1957. Por su particular emplazamiento el valle del Baztán constituía una posible vía para la hipotética invasión aliada y debido a ello fue de las zonas con mayor densidad de obras defensivas construidas. A continuación estudiaremos los principales tipos de fortificación
column5: This date represents the date the author finished the indicated version of the Learning Object.
column6: This date represents the date the author finished authoring the metadata of the indicated version of the Learning Object.
column7: 1. Conocer la realidad del valle del Baztan durante el primer franquismo.2. Comprender la táctica militar de la época y visualizar su presencia en la actualidad. 3. Mostrar preocupación por las atrocidades de la represión franquista.4. Creación e interpretación de fuentes iconográficas referidas a esta cuestión.5. Utilización de fuentes arqueológicas referidas a esta cuestión.6. Revalorización del patrimonio cercano como una fuente de enriquecimiento cultural y económico.

column13: prosiguieron hasta una fecha tan avanzada como 1957. Por su particular emplazamiento el valle del Baztán constituía una posible vía para la hipotética invasión aliada y debido a ello fue de las zonas con mayor densidad de obras defensivas construidas. column1: http://vishub.org/excursions/450#"¿Cómo identifico azúcares de la familia de la glucosa?Identificación de azúcares reductores"#"¿Cómo identifico azúcares de la familia de la glucosa?Identificación de azúcares reductores - Jose Viñas"#"Los azúcares reductores contienen un grupo aldehídico(-COH) libre que les confiere su poder reductor. Un ejemplo de estos azúcares es la glucosa.La determinación de glucosa es de importancia médica ya que niveles sanguíneos alterados pueden ser signo de una enfermedad metabólica común conocida como diabetes mellitus.

column4: - Reforzar los conocimientos adquiridos por el estudiante acerca de los  carbohidratos mediante la demostración experimental de algunas de sus propiedades.- Adquirir habilidades propias del método indagativo como :    - Identificar y especificar el objetivo de la experiencia y sus variables.    -  Relacionar el plan o procedimiento de trabajo  a las variables propuestas.    -  Elaborar hipótesis.    -  Organizar los datos obtenidos.    -  Interpretar los resultados.    -  Tiene en cuenta las posibles fuentes de error __    -   Las variables se indican en la conclusión     -  Proponer conclusiones en base a los objetivos propuestos por el profesor.- Adquirir habilidades manuales en el laboratorio: mechero

column1: http://vishub.org/excursions/496#"Biodiversitatea in Delta Dunarii "#"Biodiversitatea in Delta Dunarii  - Lidia Ristea"#"Omul își desfășoară activitatea într-un mediu natural format  din mai  multe sisteme ecologice .Conservarea biodiversităţii la nivel de ecosisteme
column2: specii şi populaţii a devenit din ce în ce mai dificilă pentru că în ultimii ani  s-a deteriorat capitalul  natural  cu efecte complexe pe termen lung
column3: datorat în mare parte intensificării  impactului uman.Unul din motivele pentru care Delta Dunării a devenit rezervaţie a biosferei este acela că
column4: în comparaţie cu alte delte ale Europei şi chiar ale Terrei
column5: a păstrat o biodiversitate mai ridicată
column6: prin aceasta întelegându-se un număr mare de specii dintr-o mare diversitate de unităţi sistematice. Mai mult decât  atât
column7: Delta Dunării frapează prin densitatea ridicată la multe specii
column8: care sunt rare sau lipsesc din alte zone ale continentului
column9: cu toate că din cauza efectelor activităţilor antropice din ultimele decenii şi efectivele acestor specii ca şi habitatele lor au fost grav afectate.

column1: http://vishub.org/excursions/283#"Bisel method in Hungary"#"Bisel method in Hungary - Agnes Bocsok"#"The Biotic IndexThe Biotic Index (BI) is a biological water quality assessment method for water courses. It is a simple method that permits one to gain a clear insight into the ecological quality of water courses with very limited means. Biological water quality assessment is a valuable supplement to chemical water quality assessment systems
column2: scientifically as well as educationally.The Belgian variant (Belgian Biotic Index
column3: BBI) was set and repeatedly tested by a cooperation of several laboratories. Since 1984 it is the offical standard method for biological water quality assessment in Belgium. This BBI  has proven to be much more applicable
column4: with slight adaptations
column6: at  least all over Europe.Concerning application at the secondary education level the  BBI has one big advantage compared to other methods (standardized elsewhere in Europe): the assessment of the biotic index is quick
column7: easy and requires no work for a specialist or big investments.In the educational field the BI integrates in an active way (field work) the biology lessons  of classifications and ecology: the  determination of the macro invertebrates is based on the principles of  the biological classification system and its interpretation in terms of water quality is connected with human influences on the environment. When the assessment of the biotic index is combined with chemical water  analyses
column8: clear conclusions can (mostly) be drawn concerning the cause of the pollution and thus we have an integration of the biology and chemistry lessons.

column11: Method:1. Sampling: try to catch as many various species of water organisms as possible.2. Sample processing: identify and enumerate them. 3. Interpretation: classify them according to their sensibility to water pollution and express your results as a score for the biological water quality.
column12: License: 'Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial'. For additional information or questions regarding copyright
column14: visit http://vishub.org/terms_of_use ."#"Slides presentation about Bisel method in Hungary. The Biotic Index

column1: The Biotic Index (BI) is a biological water quality assessment method for water courses. It is a simple method that permits one to gain a clear insight into the ecological quality of water courses with very limited means. Biological water quality assessment is a valuable supplement to chemical water quality assessment systems
column2: scientifically as well as educationally.

column1: The Belgian variant (Belgian Biotic Index
column2: BBI) was set and repeatedly tested by a cooperation of several laboratories. Since 1984 it is the offical standard method for biological water quality assessment in Belgium. This BBI  has proven to be much more applicable
column3: with slight adaptations
column4: than merely in Belgium

column1: Concerning application at the secondary education level the  BBI has one big advantage compared to other methods (standardized elsewhere in Europe): the assessment of the biotic index is quick
column2: easy and requires no work for a specialist or big investments.

column1: In the educational field the BI integrates in an active way (field work) the biology lessons  of classifications and ecology: the  determination of the macro invertebrates is based on the principles of  the biological classification system and its interpretation in terms of water quality is connected with human influences on the environment. When the assessment of the biotic index is combined with chemical water  analyses
column2: clear conclusions can (mostly) be drawn concerning the cause of the pollution and thus we have an integration of the biology and chemistry lessons.

column4: per essere protagonisti attivi in grado di porsi problemi

column14: si propone di coinvolgere studenti di ogni età
column15: dalla scuola di infanzia alle superiori
column16: nello studio delle materie scientifico tecnologiche in maniera diversa. L’apprendimento avviene emergendo dal lavoro di gruppo

column30: o studenti “difficili”.I progetti di robotica educativa sono abitualmente usati in Europa anche per migliorare l’apprendimento di genere
column31: consentendo alle ragazze di non allontanarsi dalle materie scientifico-tecnologiche.

column1: http://vishub.org/excursions/1839#"Is Radioactivity always harmful for humans?"#"Is Radioactivity always harmful for humans? - ViSH"#"This Inquiry Learning Space aims at understanding the different types of radioactivity particles and the basics about radioactivity decay. Factors that influence the radioactivity intensity (distance from radioactivity source
column2: exposure time and presence of absorbers) will also be discussed.The Radioactivity Lab examines the intensity of radiation over distance
column3: demonstrating the effects of the inverse square law. Students investigate the intensity of radiation being emitted from a radioactive Strontium-90 source
column4: by setting distances at which a Geiger counter measures radiation
column5: and collecting radioactive particle counts at each of these distances. A table holding the radioactive source is rotated until the source is aligned with a hole in a thick lead plate. The head holding the Geiger-Muller tube is moved to these distances from the radioactive source.

column1: http://vishub.org/excursions/1838#"Is it Good to be Beautiful - Understanding Evolution through Natural and Sexual Selection"#"Is it Good to be Beautiful - Understanding Evolution through Natural and Sexual Selection - ViSH"#"This inquiry activity teaches students about the importance of natural and sexual selection processes in understanding evolution. It allows students to conduct scientific experiments using the online laboratory /Sexual Selection in Guppies /and collect & analyze data just like the biologist John Endler did when he first investigated the balance of natural and sexual selection in guppy fish in the 1970s. Students work through an inquiry cycle model and acquire scientific investigative skills that actual biologists and other scientists apply when making discoveries and investigating new phenomena.

column1: http://vishub.org/excursions/1863#"pH scale ILS"#"pH scale ILS - ViSH"#"This Inquiry Learning Space is designed for young Chemistry students of lower secondary school (12-15 years old) and aims at introducing the pH concept and scale.It is based on a pHET simulation which is simple to use and involves the characterisation of familiar solutions into acids or bases. Furthermore
column2: it studies the effect of volume and dilution to the pH of a solution.The benefit of conducting this lab virtually is that students can test liquids that are normally difficult to test in “real” labs
column3: such as vomit and blood. It is also easy and quick to use and overcomes practical problems such as pH-meter calibration
column4: need of multiple instruments and resources
column5: lack of time and other educational difficulties
column6: whilst at the same time offering a fun and informative introduction to the pH scale. During this activity the students are able to conduct three different experiments:/Experiment 1: pH measurement the pH of 11 familiar liquids and classification into acids or bases/In this experiment students “test” the pH of 11 different liquids from their everyday life
column11: though the use of an electronic pH-meter
column12: which they are supposed to classify into acids or bases. Through this activity they are also included to neutral solutions./Experiment 2: Influence of volume to the pH./In this phase the students test whether volume has an effect on a liquid’s pH./Experiment 3: Influence of dilution to the pH./In this experiment students test whether dilution (the addition of water) affects a liquid’s pH and note the difference between an acid and a base
column13: as in both cases the pH approaches 7 (in the case of an acid in increases
column14: whilst in the case of a base it decreases).Throughout the activity the students are required to answer a number of questions that require critical thinking and link the concept of pH to real life (e.g. why does drinking soda pop help soothe a tummy ache).

column19: visit http://vishub.org/terms_of_use ."#"Slides presentation about pH scale ILS. This Inquiry Learning Space is designed for young Chemistry students of lower

column1: secondary school (12-15 years old) and aims at introducing the pH concept and
scale.
It is based on a pHET simulation which is simple to use and involves the
characterisation of familiar solutions into acids or bases. Furthermore
column2: it

column1: studies the effect of volume and dilution to the pH of a solution.
The benefit of conducting this lab virtually is that students can test
liquids that are normally difficult to test in “real” labs
column2: such as vomit

column1: and blood. It is also easy and quick to use and overcomes practical problems
such as pH-meter calibration
column2: need of multiple instruments and resources

column1: lack of time and other educational difficulties
column2: whilst at the same time

column1: offering a fun and informative introduction to the pH scale.
During this activity the students are able to conduct three different
experiments:
/Experiment 1: pH measurement the pH of 11 familiar liquids and
classification into acids or bases/
In this experiment students “test” the pH of 11 different liquids from
their everyday life
column2: such as blood
column3: spit
column4: soda pop

column1: though the use of an electronic pH-meter
column2: which they are supposed to classify

column1: into acids or bases. Through this activity they are also included to neutral
solutions.
/Experiment 2: Influence of volume to the pH./
In this phase the students test whether volume has an effect on a liquid’s
pH.
/Experiment 3: Influence of dilution to the pH./
In this experiment students test whether dilution (the addition of water)
affects a liquid’s pH and note the difference between an acid and a base
as in both cases the pH approaches 7 (in the case of an acid in increases
whilst in the case of a base it decreases).
Throughout the activity the students are required to answer a number of
questions that require critical thinking and link the concept of pH to real
life (e.g. why does drinking soda pop help soothe a tummy ache).

column1: http://vishub.org/excursions/1853#"Methyl orange"#"Methyl orange - ViSH"#"This ILS is based on the learning materials developed by Lisette van Rens of the VU Amsterdam. Adapted by Henny Leemkuil
column2: (Department of Instructional Technology
column3: University of Twente). In this ILS students will: * Gain knowledge about the chemistry of acids and bases and on the process   of diazotation. * Gain knowledge on the production of methyl orange in a micro reactor. * Judge the accuracy and reliability of research. * Design a 'fair' inquiry
column4: measure accurately
column5: determine whether   measurements are reliable and lead to valid conclusions. * Be part of a simulated research community and gain knowledge on peer   discussion.Pre university students will use a remote lab with real equipment. They can operate the micro reactor from their own computer and can see what they are doing by means of webcams that are situated around the micro reactor. Students have to make a reservation to use the lab for 50 minutes. The ILS will take several lessons and involves homework. Warning! To run the Methyl Orange experiment you need additional plugins for Java [1] and Silverlight [2]. [1] http://www.java.com/en/download/index.jsp[2] http://www.microsoft.com/silverlight/

column1: http://vishub.org/excursions/1887#"Star Evolution"#"Star Evolution - ViSH"#"The Sun is a yellow dwarf star at the centre of our Solar System. It is 4.5 billion years old and has converted about half of the hydrogen in its core into helium. The Sun is the most popular star. It gives life for the whole universe. It has prodigiously energy. As everyone knows the sun grows rapidly. That means
column2: the amount of his energy is growing as well. So if you install a photovoltaic module now
column3: it will produce more energy every year. This is the one and only confident chance to get unbelievably rich within at least 10 years. You will multiply your gains every year. You would be a fool
column4: if you don't use this unbelievably good chance.

column3: and performance analysis of photovoltaic systems.Thus
column4: the assessment of the effectiveness of a photovoltaic module requires knowledge of its characteristic curve.

column1: http://vishub.org/excursions/1662#"Stars Wars. Episodio I: LA AMENAZA FANTASMA."#"Stars Wars. Episodio I: LA AMENAZA FANTASMA. - Grupo investigación IES David Buján"#"Esta es una película de ciencia ficción llena de efectos especiales que innovaron el cine de aquellos años y sorprendio a todo al que la fue a ver por primera vez. En ella ademas de sorprendentes efectos especiales
column2: se describe la Galaxia desde el punto de vista de la mente creadora de esta película
column3: concretamente nos habla de un pequeño planeta llamado Naboo
column4: el cual obviamente no existe
column5: en el  se centran practicamente todos los acontecimientos que suceden a lo largo de la película.Esta nos cuenta que  la República Galáctica está sumida en el caos. Los impuestos de las rutas comerciales a los sistemas estelares exteriores están en disputa. Por otro lado esperando resolver el asunto con un bloqueo de poderosas naves de guerra
column6: la codiciosa Federación de Comercio ha detenido todos los envíos al pequeño planeta de Naboo.Para resolver este problema  el Canciller Supremo del Congreso de la Repúblicaha enviado en secreto a dos Caballeros Jedi
column7: guardianes de la paz y la justicia en la galaxia.

column8: La inteligencia interpersonal no parece depender del lenguaje  verbal.En esta excursión se invita al uso de la propia capacidad para detectar lo que quieren o no quieren expresar las personas a través de su lenguaje corporal.Esta capacidad se da en forma altamente sofisticada en los líderes religiosos y políticos
column10: en los terapeutas y en los padres.Está relacionada con dos factores peculiares de la especie humana. Uno
column11: la prolongada duración de la infancia en los primates
column12: incluyendo la estrecha relación con la madre. Cuando se sufre una pérdida en esta etapa el desarrollo interpersonal corre serio peligro. Otro factor es la importancia de la relación social para los humanos. Cazar o rastrear era una actividad de las sociedades prehistóricas que requerían la participación y cooperación de una gran cantidad de gente. La necesidad de cohesión en el grupo
column14: de organización y de solidaridad surge de forma natural. Referencias:Inteligencias múltiples. Howar Gardner.The human animal. Desmond MorrisEl lenguaje no verbal. Alan Pease

http://vishub.org/excursions/305#"ViSH Viewer (INTED 2013)"#"ViSH Viewer (INTED 2013) - Aldo"#"An effective K-12 science education is essential to succeed in future phases of the curriculum and the e-Infrastructures for education provide new opportunities to enhance it. This paper presents ViSH Viewer
column2: an innovative web tool to consume educational content which aims to facilitate e-Science infrastructures access through a next generation learning object called “Virtual Excursion”. Virtual Excursions provide a new way to explore science in class by taking advantage of e-Infrastructure resources and their integration with other educational contents
column3: resulting in the creation of a reusable
column4: interoperable and granular learning object. In order to better understand how this tool can allow teachers and students a joyful exploration of e-Science
column5: we also present three Virtual Excursion examples. Details about the design
column6: development and the tool itself are explained in this paper as well as the concept
column7: structure and metadata of the new learning object.

column1: http://vishub.org/excursions/1806#"Euglena: A Remote Online Microbiology Lab"#"Euglena: A Remote Online Microbiology Lab - ViSH"#"Welcome! This is a lab inquiry space for the Euglena laboratory. This learning space was designed primarily for 12-14 year old students.In this remote lab
column2: students can test the effects of light on the photosynthetic single-celled organism /Euglena gracilis/. The lab is located at Stanford University and houses a real /E. gracilis /population inside a microfluidic chamber that is placed under the microscope. On each side of the microfluidic chamber is an LED light; the brightness of these lights can be controlled with a virtual ""joystick"" and hence the response (or lack of response) of the /E. gracilis/ to light can be tested.Please note: we are still in the beta phase for the lab
column3: so it may be down at some times.
column4: This date represents the date the author finished the indicated version of the Learning Object.
column5: This date represents the date the author finished authoring the metadata of the indicated version of the Learning Object.
column6: License: 'Creative Commons Attribution'. For additional information or questions regarding copyright
column8: visit http://vishub.org/terms_of_use ."#"Slides presentation about Euglena: A Remote Online Microbiology Lab. Welcome! This is a lab inquiry space for the Euglena laboratory. This

column1: learning space was designed primarily for 12-14 year old students.
In this remote lab
column2: students can test the effects of light on the

column1: photosynthetic single-celled organism /Euglena gracilis/. The lab is located
at Stanford University and houses a real /E. gracilis /population inside a
microfluidic chamber that is placed under the microscope. On each side of the
microfluidic chamber is an LED light; the brightness of these lights can be
controlled with a virtual ""joystick"" and hence the response (or lack of
response) of the /E. gracilis/ to light can be tested.
Please note: we are still in the beta phase for the lab
column2: so it may be down at

column1: some times.

column7: EMF. Students acquire the skill to construct a Daniell cell. Students understand the significance of salt bridge. Students acquire the skill to calculate the electrode potential of a half cell and full cell using the Nernst equation. Students understand how the electrode potential of a given cell varies with the concentration of electrolytes in the anodic and cathodic half cell.

column8: I do not like criticizing other people's work
column9: but there are three main problems with your presentation: 1. The Higgs boson is not the solution of how all the elementary particles get masses
column10: you can do that without the Higgs for all the particles except for the W and Z bosons. 2. The question ""what did it make the difference?"" is more related with ""why the masses of the elementary particles are so different?""
column11: which is a question that the Higgs mechanism cannot answer. And 3. In page 17 you are forgetting A. Migdal and A. Polyakov
column12: which also gave an explanation for that more or less at the same time as these other people
column13: but it was forgotten because of the Iron Curtain.
column14: This presentation is only a first approximation to Higgs particle. Sure there are much more details.
column16: Very good"#"Slides presentation about HIGGS PARTICLE: Something very small that makes all the difference. A brief history of Higgs particle discovery through ideas and experiments: An excursion from the origin of the Universe to the Large Hadron Collider at CERN."#"en"#"en"#"mixed"#"null"#"[lecture

column1: http://vishub.org/excursions/1828#"How are the light fixtures in a house connected?"#"How are the light fixtures in a house connected? - ViSH"#"The basic idea of the lesson is to familiarize the students with the elements that compose a simple electric circuit (as well as electric circuits in general) and to introduce them to both parallel and in series circuit setups. After that they formulate their hypotheses and conduct scientific investigations in order to compare the electric current flowing through each light bulb between two setups (in series and parallel) and with the brightness of the bulb of a simple circuit. They will also compare the electric current flowing through each light bulb in two setups with the electric current flowing through the simple electric circuit and understand what happens to the electric current when they add more light bulbs. Then
column2: they will investigate what happens to the light bulbs in each setup if a bulb blows out. Then
column3: they will form conclusions based on the evidence collected and decide the setup that light bulbs in a house are connected.
column4: This date represents the date the author finished the indicated version of the Learning Object.
column5: This date represents the date the author finished authoring the metadata of the indicated version of the Learning Object.

column11: This video presents three cutting edge research videos
column12: carried out by Prof A. Jackson and Prof D. Gubbins
column13: on the evolution of the magnetic field through time
column14: firstly in the past using ship logs data and in the future
column15: looking at how this field could change during a pole reversal event. This video also presents the shape of the magnetic dipole as we go deeper towards the Earth's core. The oversimplified dipole evolves into a rather complex quadrupole structure.

column1: http://vishub.org/excursions/558#"¿Por qué crecemos los seres vivos?"#"¿Por qué crecemos los seres vivos? - Jose Viñas"#"Práctica de laboratorio donde se muestra la reproducción celular por mitosis.
column2: This date represents the date the author finished the indicated version of the Learning Object.
column3: This date represents the date the author finished authoring the metadata of the indicated version of the Learning Object.
column4: - En esta actividad intentaremos observar e identificar las distintas fases de la mitosis en células vegetales.- Conoceremos la influencia de algunos colorantes sobre las células vegetales.- Plantearemos hipótesis.- Resolveremos un problema experimental.- Desarrollaremos  la práctica con precisión.- Utilizaremos los diferentes equipos del laboratorio:                          - Microscopio óptico a diferentes aumentos (no objetivo de inmersión)                          - Mechero de alcohol o Bunsen.- Calidad de las observaciones. Etiquetado correcto de las distintas fases de la mitosis.

http://vishub.org/excursions/1817#"Galaxy classification and formation"#"Galaxy classification and formation - ViSH"#"This activity aims to introduce to students the concept of varying galactic morphologies. Students will look in detail at images of numerous galaxies derived from the ‘Faulkes telescopes’ and they will attempt to classify them according to their own notion and then according to the Hubble Classification Scheme. Moreover
column2: the class will try to investigate the origin of the shapes of the galaxies that stem from galaxy interactions using the “Galaxy Crash’ simulation.
